facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 27, 1957, of the Industrial Court, Bombay, at Ahmedabad in Appeal I. C. 187 of 1957.

facts.text: Bombay High Court summarily dismissed the petition of the appellants under Art. 227 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave against the order of the Bombay High Court summarily dismissing the petition of the appellants under Art. 227 of the Constitution

facts.text: Gujarat Spinning and Weaving Company Limited (old Company) closed its business on May 14, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Gujarat Spinning and Weaving Company Limited  hereinafter called the old Company  closed its business on May 14, 1953

facts.text: Old Company sold its assets to Tarun Commercial Mills Company Limited (new Company).

anchor.surface_text: closed its business on May 14, 1953 and sold its assets to the Tarun Commercial Mills Company Limited  hereinafter called the new Company .

facts.text: Old Company discharged all its workmen when it closed its business.

anchor.surface_text: The old Company had discharged all its workmen when it closed its business which happened before s. 25F

facts.text: Closure happened before s. 25F relating to retrenchment was introduced in the Industrial Disputes Act, No. XIV of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: which happened before s. 25F relating to retrenchment was introduced in the Industrial Disputes Act,  No. XIV of 1947 .

facts.text: New Company re-started the business after a week and took in its service the workmen of the old Company.

anchor.surface_text: The new Company re-started the business after a week and took in its service the workmen of the old Company.

facts.text: At the time of closure, a dispute was pending between the old Company and its workmen with respect to bonus.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that at the time the closure took place a dispute was pending between the old Company and its workmen with respect to bonus.

facts.text: Textile Labour Association (Representative Union) filed an application under s. 22 of the Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act of 1950 before the Labour Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: As the closure had taken place while that dispute was pending, the Textile Labour Association  hereinafter called the Association , which is a Representative Union of the textile workers in the city of Ahmedabad, filed an application under s. 22

facts.text: Old Company agreed to pay bonus by way of settlement to the extent of 1/8th of the earnings of the workmen for the year in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: the old Company agreed to pay bonus by way of settlement to the extent of 1/8th of the earnings of the workmen for the year in dispute

facts.text: Association on behalf of all workmen discharged as a result of closure agreed not to press for any compensation for their discharge.

anchor.surface_text: and in companysideration of this the Association on behalf of all the workmen discharged as a result of closure agreed number to press for any companypensation for their discharge

facts.text: Workmen who accepted the bonus gave undertaking not to claim compensation in any other way in any future proceeding.

anchor.surface_text: and the workmen who accepted the bonus by this agreement gave in undertaking number to claim companypensation in any other way in any future proceeding.

facts.text: This happened in March 1955.

anchor.surface_text: This happened in March 1955.

facts.text: In July 1956, 376 persons who had been in the employ of the old Company and were a minority of its workmen gave notice under s. 42(1) of the Act and claimed compensation for the closure.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter in July 1956, 376 persons who had been in the employ of the old Company and were a minority of its workmen gave numberice under s. 42 1  of the Act and claimed companypensation for the closure which had taken place in 1953.

facts.text: Application under s. 42(4) of the Act before the labour court in October 1956.

anchor.surface_text: As numbersettlement companyld be arrived at between the parties this was followed by an application under s. 42 4  of the Act before the labour companyrt in October 1956

facts.text: Old Company and new Company were made parties to the application.

anchor.surface_text: To this application both the old Company and the new Company were made parties.

facts.text: In January 1957, the Association made an appearance before the labour court.

anchor.surface_text: In January 1957, the Association made an appearance before the labour companyrt

facts.text: Labour court accepted Association's contention and dismissed the application.

anchor.surface_text: The labour companyrt accepted this companytention and dismissed the application.

facts.text: Some workmen appealed to the Industrial Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon some of the workmen went in appeal to the industrial companyrt

facts.text: Industrial Court rejected the appeal and dismissed it.

facts.text: Employees filed petition before High Court under Art. 227, which was summarily rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the employees appear to have filed a petition before the High Court under Art. 227 of the Constitution, which was summarily rejected.

facts.text: High Court refused to give leave to appeal.

issues.text: the right of a Representative Union under the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, No. XI of 1947, hereinafter called the Act to appear in a proceeding under the Act to the exclusion of an employee desiring a change under s. 42(4) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: raises an important question with regard to the right of a Representative Union under the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, No. XI of 1947,  hereinafter called the Act  to appear in a proceeding under the Act to the exclusion of an employee desiring a change under s. 42 4  of the Act.

issues.text: reading the various provisions of the Act, an employee making an application under s. 42(4) of the Act is not debarred from appearing in the labour or industrial court and carrying on with his application even though the Representative Union makes an appearance

anchor.surface_text: The main contention on behalf of the appellants before us is that reading the various provisions of the Act, an employee making an application under s. 42 4  of the Act is number debarred from appearing in the labour or industrial companyrt and carrying on with his application even though the Representative Union makes an appearance.

issues.text: where a Representative Union appears in any proceeding it alone, to the exclusion even of the employee who might have made an application under s. 42(4), is entitled to carry on with the proceedings and the employee concerned has no locus standi in the matter after the application has been filed by him, if the Representative Union chooses to appear

anchor.surface_text: The case of the respondents on the other hand is that the provisions of the Act are perfectly plain and provide that where a Representative Union appears in any proceeding it alone, to the exclusion even of the employee who might have made an application under s. 42  4 , is entitled to carry on with the proceedings and the employee companycerned has numberlocus standi in the matter after the application has been filed by him, if the Representative Union chooses to appear.

issues.text: whether the action of the Association after its appearance in not supporting the case of the workmen before the labour court was mala fide therefore the Association should not have been allowed to appear on behalf of the employees who had applied to the labour court

anchor.surface_text: their contention seems to have been that, though numberindividual can be permitted to appear in any proceeding where the Representative Union appears as representative of employees, in this case the action of the Association after its appearance in number supporting the case of the workmen before the labour companyrt was mala fide therefore the Association should number have been allowed to appear on behalf of the employees who had applied to the labour companyrt and they should be permitted to carry on their application.

issues.text: if the interpretation pressed on behalf of the respondents were accepted it would amount to tyranny of the Representative Union and this could not be the intention of the legislature in framing the Act

anchor.surface_text: It is submitted that if the interpretation pressed on behalf of the respondents were accepted it would amount to tyranny of the Representative Union and this companyld number be the intention of the legislature in framing the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 30 enumerates the representatives of employees and gives an order of preference in which the six classes of representatives of employees mentioned in that section can appear or act in any industry in any local area, the first being a Representative Union for such industry.

arguments.claim: Association is Representative Union with preferential right

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute that the Association in the present case is a Representative Union in the textile industry in that region and has the most preferential right to appear or to act as the representative of employees

holdings.text: The scheme of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act is that where a Representative Union appears in any proceeding under the Act, no one else can be allowed to appear, not even the employee at whose instance the proceedings might have begun under s. 42(4).

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear therefore that the scheme of the Act is that where a Representative Union appears in any proceeding under the Act, numberone else can be allowed to appear number even the employee at whose instance the proceedings might have begun under s. 42  4 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious reading of ss. 27A (complete ban on employee appearance except through representative), 32 and 33 (authorities' power to permit exceptions, but provisos bar permission if Representative Union has appeared) establishes exclusive position of Representative Union.

holdings.text: There can be no escape from the conclusion that the Act plainly intends that where the Representative Union appears in any proceeding under the Act even though commenced by an employee under s. 42(4), the Representative Union alone can represent and the employee cannot appear or act.

anchor.surface_text: There can therefore be numberescape from the companyclusion that the Act plainly intends that where the Representative Union appears in any proceeding under the Act even though that proceeding might have companymenced by an employee under s. 42  4  of the Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: ss. 27A, 32, 33 read together impose absolute ban once Representative Union appears; no exception for s.42(4) applicants; other representatives allow exceptions.

holdings.text: Bona fides or mala fides of the representative of employees has nothing to do with the ban placed by s. 27A on appearance of anyone else except through the representative of employees.

anchor.surface_text: But it is clear that bona fides or mala fides of the representative of employees can have numberhing to do with the ban placed by s. 27A on the appearance of any one else except the representative of employees as defined in s. 30

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.27A ban is statutory and absolute; exceptions only in ss.32,33 which do not contemplate motive inquiry; applies equally to s.42(4) applicants.

holdings.text: The argument based on the so-called tyranny of a Representative Union or its motives can have no relevance if the intention of the legislature as gathered from the provisions is perfectly plain.

anchor.surface_text: We are further of opinion that the argument based on the so-called tyranny of a Representative Union or its motives in taking the action it may choose to take in any proceeding after it appears can have numberrelevance if the intention of the legislature

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain statutory language prevails over policy consequences or purposive arguments when intent clear from text.

holdings.text: The constitutionality of the provisions has never been challenged and we therefore express no opinion as to the constitutionality of these provisions.

anchor.surface_text: Before we deal with the interpretation... we may point out that the companystitutionality of the provisions has never been challenged so far and we therefore express numberopinion as to the companystitutionality of these provisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitutionality not raised by appellants at any stage, including special leave petition.

holdings.text: In this view of the matter the appeal must fail and is hereby dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter the appeal must fail and is hereby dismissed.
